trans-unit.source: How to Use iOS Client Library for Azure Mobile Services
trans-unit.target: How to Use iOS Client Library for Azure Mobile Services

trans-unit.source: How to Use iOS Client Library for Mobile Services
trans-unit.target: How to Use iOS Client Library for Mobile Services

trans-unit.source: This guide teaches you to perform common scenarios using the Azure Mobile Services [iOS SDK].
trans-unit.target: This guide teaches you to perform common scenarios using the Azure Mobile Services [iOS SDK].

trans-unit.source: If you are new to Mobile Services, first complete [Mobile Services Quick Start] or [Add Mobile Services to Existing App] to configure your account, create a table, and create a mobile service.
trans-unit.target: If you are new to Mobile Services, first complete [Mobile Services Quick Start] or [Add Mobile Services to Existing App] to configure your account, create a table, and create a mobile service.

trans-unit.source: This guide uses the latest <linkText>iOS Mobile Services SDK</linkText><title></title>. If your project uses an older version of the SDK, first upgrade the framework in Xcode.
trans-unit.target: This guide uses the latest <linkText>iOS Mobile Services SDK</linkText><title></title>. If your project uses an older version of the SDK, first upgrade the framework in Xcode.

trans-unit.source: This guide assumes that you have created a mobile service with a table.
trans-unit.target: This guide assumes that you have created a mobile service with a table.

trans-unit.source: For more information see [Create a table], or reuse the TodoItem table created in [Mobile Services Quick Start] or [Add Mobile Services to Existing App].
trans-unit.target: For more information see [Create a table], or reuse the TodoItem table created in [Mobile Services Quick Start] or [Add Mobile Services to Existing App].

trans-unit.source: This guide assumes that the table has the same schema as the tables in those tutorials.
trans-unit.target: This guide assumes that the table has the same schema as the tables in those tutorials.

trans-unit.source: This guide also assumes that your Xcode references WindowsAzureMobileServices.framework and imports WindowsAzureMobileServices/WindowsAzureMobileServices.h.
trans-unit.target: This guide also assumes that your Xcode references WindowsAzureMobileServices.framework and imports WindowsAzureMobileServices/WindowsAzureMobileServices.h.

trans-unit.source: To access an Azure mobile service in your project, create an MSClient client object.
trans-unit.target: To access an Azure mobile service in your project, create an MSClient client object.

trans-unit.source: Replace AppUrl and AppKey with the mobile service URL and the application key Dashboard values, respectively.
trans-unit.target: Replace AppUrl and AppKey with the mobile service URL and the application key Dashboard values, respectively.

trans-unit.source: To access or update data for your Azure mobile service, create a reference to the table.
trans-unit.target: To access or update data for your Azure mobile service, create a reference to the table.

trans-unit.source: Replace TodoItem with the name of your table.
trans-unit.target: Replace TodoItem with the name of your table.

trans-unit.source: To create a database query, query the MSTable object.
trans-unit.target: To create a database query, query the MSTable object.

trans-unit.source: The following query gets all the items in TodoItem and logs the text of each item.
trans-unit.target: The following query gets all the items in TodoItem and logs the text of each item.

trans-unit.source: To filter results, there are many available options.
trans-unit.target: To filter results, there are many available options.

trans-unit.source: To filter using a predicate, use an NSPredicate and readWithPredicate.
trans-unit.target: To filter using a predicate, use an NSPredicate and readWithPredicate.

trans-unit.source: The following filters returned data to find only incomplete Todo items.
trans-unit.target: The following filters returned data to find only incomplete Todo items.

trans-unit.source: To perform a complex query (including sorting and paging), create an MSQuery object, directly or by using a predicate:
trans-unit.target: To perform a complex query (including sorting and paging), create an MSQuery object, directly or by using a predicate:

trans-unit.source: MSQuery lets you control several query behaviors, including the following.
trans-unit.target: MSQuery lets you control several query behaviors, including the following.

trans-unit.source: Execute an MSQuery query by calling readWithCompletion on it, as shown in the next example.
trans-unit.target: Execute an MSQuery query by calling readWithCompletion on it, as shown in the next example.

trans-unit.source: Specify order of results
trans-unit.target: Specify order of results

trans-unit.source: Limit which fields to return
trans-unit.target: Limit which fields to return

trans-unit.source: Limit how many records to return
trans-unit.target: Limit how many records to return

trans-unit.source: Specify total count in response
trans-unit.target: Specify total count in response

trans-unit.source: Specify custom query string parameters in request
trans-unit.target: Specify custom query string parameters in request

trans-unit.source: Apply additional functions
trans-unit.target: Apply additional functions

trans-unit.source: To sort results, let's look at an example.
trans-unit.target: To sort results, let's look at an example.

trans-unit.source: To first ascendingly by field text and then descendingly by field completion, invoke MSQuery like so:
trans-unit.target: To first ascendingly by field text and then descendingly by field completion, invoke MSQuery like so:

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services limits the amount of records that are returned in a single response.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services limits the amount of records that are returned in a single response.

trans-unit.source: To control the number of records displayed to your users you must implement a paging system.
trans-unit.target: To control the number of records displayed to your users you must implement a paging system.

trans-unit.source: Paging is performed by using the following three properties of the MSQuery object:
trans-unit.target: Paging is performed by using the following three properties of the MSQuery object:

trans-unit.source: In the following example, a simple function requests 5 records from the server and then appends them to the local collection of previously loaded records:
trans-unit.target: In the following example, a simple function requests 5 records from the server and then appends them to the local collection of previously loaded records:

trans-unit.source: To limit fields to be returned in a query, specify the names of the fields in the selectFields property.
trans-unit.target: To limit fields to be returned in a query, specify the names of the fields in the selectFields property.

trans-unit.source: This returns only the text and completed fields:
trans-unit.target: This returns only the text and completed fields:

trans-unit.source: To include additional query string parameters in the server request (for example, because a custom server-side script uses them), populate query.parameters like so:
trans-unit.target: To include additional query string parameters in the server request (for example, because a custom server-side script uses them), populate query.parameters like so:

trans-unit.source: To insert a new table row, create a new NSDictionary and invoke table insert.
trans-unit.target: To insert a new table row, create a new NSDictionary and invoke table insert.

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services automatically generates new columns based on the NSDictionary if [Dynamic Schema] is not disabled.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services automatically generates new columns based on the NSDictionary if [Dynamic Schema] is not disabled.

trans-unit.source: If id is not provided, the backend automatically generates a new unique ID.
trans-unit.target: If id is not provided, the backend automatically generates a new unique ID.

trans-unit.source: Provide your own id to use email addresses, usernames, or your own custom values as ID.
trans-unit.target: Provide your own id to use email addresses, usernames, or your own custom values as ID.

trans-unit.source: Providing your own ID may ease joins and business-oriented database logic.
trans-unit.target: Providing your own ID may ease joins and business-oriented database logic.

trans-unit.source: To update an existing row, modify an item and call update:
trans-unit.target: To update an existing row, modify an item and call update:

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, supply the row ID and the updated field:
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, supply the row ID and the updated field:

trans-unit.source: At minimum, the id attribute must be set when making updates.
trans-unit.target: At minimum, the id attribute must be set when making updates.

trans-unit.source: To delete an item, invoke delete with the item:
trans-unit.target: To delete an item, invoke delete with the item:

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, delete by providing a row ID:
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, delete by providing a row ID:

trans-unit.source: At minimum, the id attribute must be set when making deletes.
trans-unit.target: At minimum, the id attribute must be set when making deletes.

trans-unit.source: Azure Mobile Services supports various identity providers.
trans-unit.target: Azure Mobile Services supports various identity providers.

trans-unit.source: For a basic tutorial, see [Authentication].
trans-unit.target: For a basic tutorial, see [Authentication].

trans-unit.source: Azure Mobile Services supports two authentication workflows:
trans-unit.target: Azure Mobile Services supports two authentication workflows:

trans-unit.source: Server-managed Login: Azure Mobile Services manages the login process on behalf of your app.
trans-unit.target: Server-managed Login: Azure Mobile Services manages the login process on behalf of your app.

trans-unit.source: It displays a provider-specific login page and authenticates with the chosen provider.
trans-unit.target: It displays a provider-specific login page and authenticates with the chosen provider.

trans-unit.source: Client-managed Login: The app requests a token from the identity provider and presents this token to Azure Mobile Services for authentication.
trans-unit.target: Client-managed Login: The app requests a token from the identity provider and presents this token to Azure Mobile Services for authentication.

trans-unit.source: When authentication succeeds, you get back a user object with a user ID value and the auth token.
trans-unit.target: When authentication succeeds, you get back a user object with a user ID value and the auth token.

trans-unit.source: To use this user ID to authorize users, see [Service-side Authorization].
trans-unit.target: To use this user ID to authorize users, see [Service-side Authorization].

trans-unit.source: To restrict table access to only authenticated users, see [Permissions].
trans-unit.target: To restrict table access to only authenticated users, see [Permissions].

trans-unit.source: Here is how you can add server-managed login to the [Mobile Services Quick Start] project; you may use similar code for your other projects.
trans-unit.target: Here is how you can add server-managed login to the [Mobile Services Quick Start] project; you may use similar code for your other projects.

trans-unit.source: For more information and to see an end-to-end example in action, see [Authentication].
trans-unit.target: For more information and to see an end-to-end example in action, see [Authentication].

trans-unit.source: You may do the login process outside the Mobile Services client, either to enable single sign-on or if your app contacts the identity provider directly.
trans-unit.target: You may do the login process outside the Mobile Services client, either to enable single sign-on or if your app contacts the identity provider directly.

trans-unit.source: In such cases, you can log in to Mobile Services by providing a token obtained independently from a supported identity provider.
trans-unit.target: In such cases, you can log in to Mobile Services by providing a token obtained independently from a supported identity provider.

trans-unit.source: The following example uses the [Live Connect SDK] to enable single sign-on for iOS apps.
trans-unit.target: The following example uses the [Live Connect SDK] to enable single sign-on for iOS apps.

trans-unit.source: It assumes that you have a LiveConnectClient instance named liveClient in the controller and the user is logged in.
trans-unit.target: It assumes that you have a LiveConnectClient instance named liveClient in the controller and the user is logged in.

trans-unit.source: Let's see how you may cache tokens in the [Mobile Services Quick Start] project; you may apply similar steps to any project.
trans-unit.target: Let's see how you may cache tokens in the [Mobile Services Quick Start] project; you may apply similar steps to any project.

trans-unit.source: When you call a mobile service, the completion block contains an NSError *error parameter.
trans-unit.target: When you call a mobile service, the completion block contains an NSError *error parameter.

trans-unit.source: When an error occurs, this parameter is non-nil.
trans-unit.target: When an error occurs, this parameter is non-nil.

trans-unit.source: In your code, you should check this parameter and handle the error as needed.
trans-unit.target: In your code, you should check this parameter and handle the error as needed.

trans-unit.source: The file [](https://github.com/Azure/azure-mobile-services/blob/master/sdk/iOS/src/MSError.h) defines the constants MSErrorResponseKey, MSErrorRequestKey, and MSErrorServerItemKey to get more data related to the error. In addition, the file defines constants for each error code. For an example on how to use these constants, see [Conflict-Handler] for its usage of MSErrorServerItemKey and MSErrorPreconditionFailed.
trans-unit.target: The file [](https://github.com/Azure/azure-mobile-services/blob/master/sdk/iOS/src/MSError.h) defines the constants MSErrorResponseKey, MSErrorRequestKey, and MSErrorServerItemKey to get more data related to the error. In addition, the file defines constants for each error code. For an example on how to use these constants, see [Conflict-Handler] for its usage of MSErrorServerItemKey and MSErrorPreconditionFailed.
